content:
16, 2015
												First of all, I'd like to point out that I have atleast 20+ hours game time on this game but played it mostly outside steam.This is one of those games that was given a unique touch on it's style. So, if you're the type of person who looks for "something different" in games then, this one is for you.Don't Starve is a survival game with an art inspired from Tim Burton's works. Now don't get that statement get to you as it surprisingly fit the game overall. You are dropped in a random-generated world and start of from them. The game has no tutorials but its easy to get the gist of the game while at the same time It's hard to master.Controls[+] The game works well on both mouse/WASD controls depending on your preference.[+] Zoom in feature.[+] Full controller support.Sounds[+] Atmospheric OST.[+] Good choice of SFX for small things like picking flints.Graphics[+] Tim Burton style. The art for characters, monsters, and objects blends well with the world.Balance[+] Challenging. You can spend a lot of hours playing the game and you will still have a hard time surviving for a long time especially for winter.[+] Different kinds of monsters, objects, and resources spawn near you each time you start off a new world.[+] You will have to do more than just picking up items and cutting pine trees if you want to craft advanced items.[+] Multiple characters to unlock. One has more advantage than the other but still keeping the balance to keep the difficulty of the game.Others[+] Dialogues to keep you from getting bored playing in a gloomy atmosphere.[+] Huge in-game content.[+] The type of survival game where survival is your real concern.[] No story. Although it doesn't need one, it wouldn't hurt to have one.[-] It could use a short and justified tutorial for some players who can't get into games quickly.[-] Craftable materials appearing and disappearing while moving away from machines can be confusing at times.

content:
er 25, 2013
												Don't Starve is a wilderness survival game.  You are left in a world to explore, set up camp, and above everything else... Don't Starve!   Here's my review as a disabled gamer (I play with only a mouse).


YouTube™ Video: Can I Play... Don't Starve? 

			Views: 222		

			Are you a disabled gamer... ever saw a game, and wondered "Can I Play That"? Do you need to see options and settings for accessibility? You're not alone! Join me as I test options and find out...		

Don't Starve begins in Full Screen but you can immediately access options to change to windowed mode.  Windowed mode is borderless so you can access your desktop without exiting the game.  No colorblind settings were in the options.  Mouse only gamers can play with ease.  When you start this game you may not see your friends or family for weeks...  the game is just that good!  Everything can be controlled with simple mouse clicks, a few keyboard buttons can help you lower your right clicking and adjust camera settings.  You can left click to move your character collect objects or attack.  For keyboard only gamers the news isn't as good.  You can walk using wasd & collect items with space.  My problem came when trying to access build menus.  I personally never found a key to access them and looking through forum posts I failed to find a solution.  If keybindings do become available,  I'll definitely update notes here!

content:
ry 4, 2014
												A very challenging and fun game, Don't Starve brings us the creativity of Minecraft and the adventure of Terraria and mash them together with some lovely art. You play *mainly* as Wilson, a scientist who was whisked away into this hellish world of violent trees, annoying hellhounds, and a deadly night. Although this game is quite challenging, and yes, frustrating, it is a lot of fun to play and experience for yourself. There are gameplay mechanics such as sanity, hunger, and weather. As you see more disturbing things, your sanity drops, making shadows and other hallucinations appear at night, and eventually, at day. Hunger is, obviously, a big problem. As you go throughout your day with food in your inventory, it will decompose and spoil. To combat this, you either eat it or store it in an ice box. Even so, your food still isn't completely safe in the ice box. Finally, there is rain, lightning, snow, and more snow. As the winter months draw near, you will be forced to stay near your fire unless you have the proper attire. Each and every enemy in this game is basically out for your head as well. The hellhounds will come every once in a while to remind you to stay on guard. Swamps come alive with deadly spiked tentacles that lash out if you get too close. Pigmen will defend their brethren to the death if need be. All of this comes with a grim reminder that to survive, you must always be alert, unless you want a beefalo horn shoved up your bum. 9/10 overall score

content:
, 2016
												This game is HARD.  You get thrown into it with no tutorial, no explanation and no help.  Not gonna lie - I ended up looking a lot of things up at the beginning because I don't deal with these types of games very well.  However, you learn quickly and it gets to the point where you don't care why you're in this other world, why there are shadow creatures trying to kill you, etc.  You just have to survive.  There's a lot of item collection and the opportunity to build bigger and better defenses, offenses, etc. There's no real right or wrong way to play this game.  You will probably die a lot but there is tons of replayability.

												Don't Starve is a 2013 action-adventure video game with survival and roguelike elements, developed and published by the Canadian indie company Klei Entertainment. The game was initially released via Valve's Steam software for Microsoft Windows, OS X, and Linux on April 23, 2013. A PlayStation 4 port became available the following year and further versions for iOS and mobile phones are under consideration. Downloadable content titled Reign of Giants was released on April 30, 2014, and a multiplayer expansion called Don't Starve Together became free for existing users on June 3, 2015.[1]The game follows a scientist named Wilson who finds himself in a dark, dreary world and must survive as long as possible. Toward this end, the player must keep Wilson healthy, fed, and mentally stable as he avoids a variety of surreal and supernatural enemies that will try to kill and devour him. The game's "Adventure" mode adds depth to the sparse plot and pits Wilson against the game's antagonist, Maxwell.Time by time, you unlock more valuable and specific-abilities characters.'Rate: 11/10

er 10, 2014
												This game really turned me against myself. A part of me really liked the game, while another was eagerly waiting to get off. Dont Starve is a survival game that blends a unique style of artwork with a fasinating story. By all means, the story is very well done and the gameplay is not bad, and if you like survival this is the game for you, but somewhere it just failed. It failed when it came to replay value, or how much you can play a game after you have finished it once. i felt that it started getting repetetive, doing the same things over and over for the same objective. Overall, i do recommend this game to anyone who loves survival, but i would only buy it if it were on sale.

content:
, 2016
 Don't Starve: Shipwrecked  is a standalone expansion to the base survival game  Don't Starve . Let it be known that I have not played the original game to any extent and my impressions are based on the expansion and its content.  Narrative  The narrative is entirely freeform and allows the player to create their own story according to personal playstyle. Your enjoyment in this regard is mostly limited to your own imagination. However, each playable character has his or her own personality quirks, quips and unique gameplay interactions. For example, my favorite character is a snotty librarian who is able to bypass certain tech restrictions due to her vast intelligence and in exchange is unwilling to eat spoiled food.   Gameplay  Due to the nature of permadeath games, the player's response to death is paramount to whether or not the game succeeds. When the player inevitably sees the "You died" screen, frustration will be a natural response. However, does the player feel enticed to try again? Has the player learned valuable information that will serve to prevent the same death from occurring?  Don't Starve: Shipwrecked  succeeds for the most part in this regard. For example, at a predetermined time a certain mob will spawn and attack the player. This acts as a test to see if the player has adequately prepared. The first time I had to fight this mob, I instantly died - I was  not  prepared. How could I be? I did not know that the pounding footsteps and the shaking ground were signs of my coming death. However, during my second attempt, I realized that this certain mobs' movements were incredibly predictable and burdened with a long attack animation. I kited them and dispatched them with ease. Five minutes later, while congratulating myself with a hearty vegetable stew, I was punched to mincemeat by a enraged ent revenging his fallen children who I had unwittingly used as my kindling for said stew. And so the ouroboric cycle of punishment/information/success/punishment continued. During the downtime when you are not being chased by rabid sharks or angry buffalo, you will spend your time traveling from island to island in search of new materials, new technologies and establishing bases of operation. There is also a beautiful settings menu with ample customization options for certain mobs/events/seasons/resources to be tweaked, increased or even removed. Do you really love picking berries? Increase the berry bush seed. Do you HATE @#(%@^( KLEPTOMANIC MONKEYS? Remove the monkeys... Or just feed them a banana next time, recruit them permamently, and start a primate civil war. Watch their monkey huts burn down; watch the baby monkeys scream for mercy while you lounge by the shore sipping some iced tea and listening to Rage Against the Machine. Sensory  The art style looks like the baby of The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker and American McGee's Alice: sharp lines and bright, contrasting colors all wrapped up in a twisted design. You will never look so good being mutilated over and over again. The sounds are interesting, unique, and did not devolve into repetition. However, the musical soundtrack needed more variance - I eventually listened to my own music and was perfectly content. Conclusion  Do you enjoy being slapped in the face repeatedly by someone other than your wife? Do you relish the idea of convincing monkeys to murder each other with their own feces? Are you titillated by the notion of spending five hours building an empire only to die from a coconut falling on your head?  Do you enjoy complex games with a myriad of gameplay elements which allow you to play your own game against the game? If you said yes to the above then  Don't Starve: Shipwrecked  is a game definitely worth dying.

content:
ber 27, 2016
												Let's make it quick: I believe Don't Starve is the best sandbox survival game in the market. Whatever the price, the lower the better. Just buy it. The DLC as well, especially the multiplayer standalone expansion: Don't Starve Together. Why?Because it's really well made right from the start. Don't Starve has a very robust system in place within the gameplay. Despite being a survival game, it plays out almost like a 4X strategy. To survive, you need to eXplore the world. eXploit its riches, eXpand yourself and your base of operation, and eXterminate the enemies that threaten your life. Except you're just playing a guy, not an empire or somethingThe visual is fantastic. It has a very distinguished art style that people can easily recognize. The animation is smooth like a cartoon on TV. The characters are all unique and plays very differently. The monster are varied with its challenge and the world, oh the world... It pose a lot of question. It begs to be explored.It's really great that the devs didn't cop out with retro pixel art like a lot of other indie game out there and it really shows. Very few of those game looks decent and most simply look terrible. Don't Starve is a proof that hiring actual artist is worth it.I absolutely have fun playing the game and can't reccommend it enough.EDIT: I nominated this game for Steam "Steam Best Use of Farm Animal" Award

												This game is addicting.The style of the game in my opinion fits this scenario and the humor behind it is clever.The game offers you countless hours of fun and plenty of stuff to do around.One thing I love about it is the fact that once you're dead..you're dead.This makes you stay in constant fear of losing all of the progress and this fear only intensifies with the progress you make.Again,the number of things you can do are almost countless.You can set a whole forest on fire just because you want to or because you want to kill something that is after you!You can explore caves and fight bats and spiders or just build yourself a small town from which you can sustain yourself without exploring.You can choose to be a explorer and wander from one place to another to try and discover new creatures and new resources.The replay ability of this game is insane due to the fact that the game has tons of good mods and that the devs put so much work into releasing a lot of free updates.Also the game randomly generates the world,that means you will never have the same experience twice.

content:
er 30, 2014
												Jeeeeeeesuuussssssssssssss, I just love this game. When I first booted it up, I was perfectly normal about it. I didn't think much of it in the game menu, but immediately when I spawned in my first world, a man appeared and said I have to prepare food and shelter before dark, I am on my own, and he drops me off in the middle of nowhere. Right when I saw him, I cracked a jolly smile. The man was tall, in a suit, holding a briefcase, and with dark brown hair. Sound familiar? Yes. Very. What? Dafuq? Not familiar? Well, let me give you a hint. GMAAANNNNN. Yea, NOW, does it sound familiar? required resources are randomly scattered along the terrian, and different biomes containing many useful resources. The great thing about these resources, is just so cool. Picked up something useless? Not possible. Everything has it's own purpose. I just love that. When The day turns to night, EVERYTHING GOES BLACK. Im not kidding you, EVERYTHING goes black. And you get hit by... something... And you die in a matter of seconds. This, of course, can be avoided by building a torch or a campfire, which are very cheap items. There are so many good things about this game, if I listed all of them, this review would be 45 paragraphs long, so I'm just gonna stop writing here. I highly recommend this game and if you have a spare 15 bucks, buy it. Immediately. Or I'll eat you. Well, anyways thanks for reading, goodbye!

												Very addictive and unique game that really makes you feel like you are accomplishing something when you do it right, and punishes you when you do it wrong. Expect to fail the first dozen times you play, but it is just a learning curve. If you stick it out you WILL live through that first winter and when you see it rain for the first time after a winter of snow, or when you see the Redbirds come back the feeling you will get is worth the price of the game. Only made it to day 67 so far and the reason I died was because I decided to explore a swamp in winter, stupid idea. I never felt like the game screwed me over, it is always poor planning that does you in, and that is what makes this game great in my opinion.

content:
er 22, 2013
												"Don't Starve" is an amazing survival game that manages to merge the beauty of Tim Burton's well known art style together with the normal aspects of survival that you'd find in games like Terraria or Minecraft.It's a game that'll challenge you, even if you get the hang of things. It's a dark, twisted survival game where even the friendly pigs will eventually try to kill you. To survive, you will have to scavenge, build things, and defend yourself - all while paying attention to both the environment and your own wellness (hunger, mentality & health). The developers of the game (Klei Entertainment) are also constantly adding new content to the game, making it a game that'll offer hours of endless fun (and to times, bits of frustration too).Conclusion: Buy it.

												If you don't have this game in your library yet. You have to get it. It's an amazing sandbox and survival game with Tim Burton-esque art style. You'll never get the same world twice, and the adventure mode is really challenging. If someone tells you that they already did everything in Don't Starve and have less than 10 hours, they're lying, there's TONS of stuff to do, Get through winter, fight bosses, explore the caves and the ancient ruins, and if you get bored, assemble the Wooden Thing and change characters in a new world to make it a much challenging or different experience. The devs are amazing and keep the game fresh. Currently waiting for the Fall DLC. They also try to respond to all e-mails personally as well as comments on their Facebook page. Also since the addition of workshop you can improve your game and have a lot more things to do. I love this game and every aspect of it. 10/10

content:
y 16, 2016
												10/10Easily the diamond of the survival genre, with so many unique and wonderful ideas.  Don't starve is a unique take on said genre, with an almost 'cute' gothic tim burton esque aesthetic containing characters that literally exist purely to make your life a misery, chase you, eat you, crush you, sting you, hunt you, steal your ♥♥♥♥, evict you, destroy you and your base, backstab you, become mobile npc bases that still hate you and there is even an npc that goes on a spree looting the map of all resources. I can remember when this first came out and played from like 7pm until about 4am one time and i loved every second. The game starts you off with no tutorial or explanation to anything at all. You are required to fend for yourself in this unforgiving land of permadeath and bees, and if you are the more casual sort of player i'd highly recommend giving the wiki a look as it may explain some things. You must fend for yourself, build a camp, set up crops and as the title implies...don't starve. But starving is the least of your worries. Everything in this game exists to murder you in ways you never thought possible. On top of that, you must worry about your sanity, temperature and health as well. Too many spider bites and you'll die. Been out in the night for too long? You'll go insane and even the shadows will be out to kill you. Oh look, it's become winter! Good luck, because you'll need to wear some nice warm clothes or you'll freeze to death! The game does have some less than lethal additions to it as well. You can come across villages of friendly pig men who you can befriend and trade with, which is wonderful since they are can sometimes be farmers, giving you free resources, food and even defence as the pig men are rather hostile towards monsters.This game really is bursting at the seams with content here and the maps are even randomly generated to ensure that no playthrough is like another. Even if you manage to "beat" survival mode by finding all of the tele-portato parts an exploring the cave systems for super duper loot, you can always play campaign for increasingly hard scenarios that are really fun as well. Avoid bees. Avoid all the bees.

content:
, 2013
A while back I reviewed this as boring, basic and lacking. And it was. I played during the first days of release, and didn't give it enough time to get interesting. After sinking a ton of hours into this and still finding new things to want to check out, mess around with, explore and unlock, it's safe to say Don't Starve is a well made and interesting game.It's stacked with charm and intrigue. It still has a dead end in terms of discovery, tech and gameplay, like any survival or city sim game, but it's going to take you a lot longer to get there in Don't Starve than most other games. It's also fuelled by lots of strange little gameplay mechanics and items that you find along the way.I haven't even touched the DLC yet, and I'm not the greatest fan of survival games, but Don't Starve has definitely given me my moneys worth after investing a little time and effort.Pretty boring survival game. Don't Starve starts off with the same feeling you get playing Minecraft for the first time: You want to collect food and items to survive the first night and it's pretty exciting and fun.Unfortunately this is about it, and after the first few days of experimenting and finding out what everything does all you're left with is exploring and fighting. Fighting never really seems very exciting and has no real purpose other than maybe collecting items, and exploring seems like a waste of time since it doesn't help you survive any longer (which ultimately is the goal of the game). As a result this game gets boring very quickly and there doesn't appear to be much to do.Pretty boring survival game.

content:
17, 2016
 Long Story ShortDon’t Starve is an extremely difficult masterpiece that will take you 50+ hours in order to learn how to survive in this unforgiving universe. The art style is unique and the sounds/music is beautiful and creepy.  The game play is outstanding and it will, whether you want it to or not, draw you in for hours of game time without giving you a chance to take a break. You’ll probably starve in real life before you can put your controller down. It’s without a doubt a 10/10 and is one of the few games I think couldn’t even be improved upon. Long Story Long- The Game PlayDon’t Starve is a survival game and therefore your only natural objective is to survive. This is accomplished by keeping your sanity, hunger, heath, warmth, and sogginess in check. In order to do so, you’ll gather resources, make your camp, plant crops, craft recipes, etc. in order to create a working outpost. The game will constantly become more difficult as Maxwell, the villain, sends his hounds to attack you, you run out of any resource, and then there is the ever looming threat of winter. Variations to the game playThis game is almost 100% customizable whether you want more or less tall birds, no winter, or if you want to commit suicide by making it permanently night.  There are also several unlockable characters that all have different stats, starting items, and uses. Lastly, you can, if you’re lucky enough to find a rare portal where you’re able to switch to adventure mode where you are plopped in a premade world, opposed to the randomly generated worlds in survival mode, where you attempt to live past the more increasingly difficult worlds you’re put into in order to make it to the next and, eventually, toss Maxwell off his throne of lies!Music and SoundThe creators of Don’t Starve cut no corners when it comes to the music and sound effects. The music is beautiful, exiting, and darn right creepy depending on the circumstances. In fact, me and my roommate once did a scientific experiment in order to see if playing frightening music, in this case music from Don’t Starve, at night while we were asleep would affect our dreams or not. We both had nightmares. The sound is also perfect for whatever action is happening. I often want to eat my food reserve just so I can hear Wilson munching away at the meat or kill a spider so I can hear it shriek.ArtThe art style for Don’t Starve is completely original and shows character for objects through its harsh strokes or gentile lines. Combined with the music and sound, the art gives the player a perfect atmosphere that, in my opinion, has never been matched by another survival game.DLC and Don’t Starve TogetherThe DLC for Don’t Starve, Reign of Giants, adds craftibles, items, enemies, and even two whole freaking seasons! If you ask me, this DLC adds difficulty and challenge to this already challenging game and, unless you’ve played lots of survival games, I wouldn’t suggest using it till you’ve at least made it till winter in the normal version. As far as Don’t Starve Together goes, it adds a little content as well as making the game significantly easier. I’d suggest you’d get it if you’ve already bought and liked the original but find yourself wanting to shake things up by tossing in some other players. ConclusionGame play- 10/10. Music and sound- 10/10. Customizability - 10/10. Art style- 10/10. DLC- 10/10. This is the best survival game I’ve ever played or ever seen played.  It’s addicting, entertaining, and challenging. Without a doubt it’s one of my top ten favorite games. It’s also one of four games I think is as flawless as humanly possible.  Oh course, like all games, there is those who won’t enjoy it. So if you’re someone who doesn’t normally enjoy intense, extremely difficult games, the most likely won’t find Don’t Starve appealing. However, to anyone that doesn’t fall in this category, I’ll say this: Don’t Starve is a chef-d'oeuvre, a masterpiece beyond words, perfected in every way, and I can’t suggest it enough. Final rating- 100/100 one of the few perfect games on this earth.

5, 2014
												The game really revolves around collecting basic ingredients and crafting them into survival gear/items. You are going to want to collect food RIGHT away, you will get hungry fast. You are going to want to cook this food with fire. You are also going to want to build tools like axes, pickaxes, etc and harvest quite a bit of raw materials. Then you are going to want to build science machines in order to build better tools/survival gear/weapons.Combat is fairly basic, click and run is the general tactic. I really think this is a wiki friendly game despite spoilers. You should learn about what items you want and how to craft them by searching a wiki.This is really a fun game.  The Devs have released a ton of content and fixes since then and continue to update once a month or so. And the good part is if you have a low - end pc you can run it though with the netbook modus.

content:
er 16, 2015
												In its minimal and simple atmosphere, Don't Starve succeeded where many failed: delivering a balanced, challenging and story driven survival game.As the obvious main focus is to survive (and how hard it can be at the beginning!), the player will progress through a story that has an impact in the game (trying to avoid any potential spoilers).The survival machanism is traditional and unique at the same time:There are many resources to loot, and several items can have multiple uses (for example pine cones can be planted, used as fuel to feed the fire or become crafting material); exploring the land around you not only gets you to secret or story-related areas, but also signals how the world changes due to nature rhythm (for example seasons will progress and according to them resources may grow again faster or slowlier, the day/night cycle will change), moreover, it is always best NOT to explore during the night: the land becomes completely dark, pitch dark, and creatures will literally devour you unless you have a source of light, so it's best to build a safe place and dedicate the night to crafting and refining materials you gathered in the day.Crafting and researching new "technologies" is, of course, the vital part of the game. You start with some basic knowledge of craftable items, but you need to build scientific buildings (and stand next to them) to unlock more advanced options.The grotesque atmosphere is one of the winning points of this game: everything is weird and questionable, from totem-adoring pigs to crawling shadows. The overall feeling of Don't Starve is similar to when you read a fantasy book, curled up in your bed sheet as a thunder storm is raging from afar.If you love survival games, dark settings and challenging stories, get this game!

content:
2015
												Wow.....I knew I would enjoy this game...but I did not expect to put 250 + hours in it and still going! I had not played minecraft before this but it is cleat that Don't Starve takes the survival aspects of that game and totally runs with it...making the experience more brutal and tense. It is hard because you die...alot. But around the 12th time or so you start to learn what to do and what NOT to do. Once you pass the amount of days you've stayed alive...you feel a sense of accomplishment! Then you just try to beat your record over and over. But the game isn't just about that...there is a mysterious charm to it and very deep! There is a story even! Its hidden. Also, there is additional game modes that can only be accessed by putting time in the game and exploring. There's too much to say about the game....to newcomers...I would say give it time and enjoy the challenge and charm...try new things and eventually the game will click for you! I give it a 10/10....amazing job Klei!

												This is the best survival game I have ever played. If you love survival, you are not doing yourself any favors by avoiding this game. It throws you to the wolves and does not hold your hand. Yes, the graphics are cartoony, but dont be fooled. This game will test your skills and you will die and die and die again. Grab the DLC's and you have a beast of a challenge to survive. Especially the new Shipwrecked DLC.I have owned this game for years and still keep coming back. The mechanics are deceptively simple, pick up as much stuff as you can and start trying to figure out how to survive. Not starving is only one priority. You will want to set up a camp and start doing science to unlock the best stuff. You will also have weather and heat and cold to contend with on top of the fact that nearly everything will try and kill you in one way or another. Caves add another layer of challange to the game with multiple levels of darkness and monsters to explore. You cook, build, explore, fight, and science the ♥♥♥♥ out of things to try and survive.Use Wiki or Youtube to help get started.Overall this game is one of my favorite all time games. Do yourself a favor and buy it now if you dont own it.

content:
6, 2014
												I've been playing games since I was 8 years old. I'm 21 now and I can tell you that this is one of the best games I have played in my entire life.With that said, I want to tell you why this game is so good.1st and most important of all is; this is a survival game. Meaning hard difficulty and permanent death. Even though, you can customize the world to your liking and survive with your conditions. The default version being the intended difficulty.2nd is the gameplay. You can move with clicking your mouse, just like in any Diablo-esque games. You can move with ASDW (which I prefer and recommend). It's simple to play and is very responsive. The game is simple in graphics and has really good animations (meaning anyone can play it!). The music and sounds are awesome but they might become repetitive at some point (at which you just turn them off :D). This may be one downside that bothered me a bit, but it is not a big problem at all.3rd is the game itself, you are placed inside a world where you are only told that you should look for something to eat. Don't starve is not nearly the only danger you should look out for. You have to stay warm in the Winter, stay cool in the Summer, protect your things, avoid monsters, kill monsters, survive giants, maintain sanity. But more importantly, you build structures, walls, farms, protective structures, traps, weapons, tools. Furthermore, you explore secrets, caves, biomes, animals, monsters, items! There are so many options in this game to explore. I have 40-ish hours on this game (for now) and I have only explored barely half of all the things that can be done. I haven't even customized the starting world yet! I've been playing default untill I got the hang of it. But the number of settings and customizations you can make to your world are nearly endless! You can also unlock other characters which all have different perks and abillities.4th and last are the community mods that can expand and improve your game greatly (I'm using 8 mods at the moment). Not to mention the upcoming multiplayer that will allow you and your friends to experience this survival game in a world that has your rules and settings.I highly recommend this game to anyone that likes: survival / fighting / building and crafting stuff.Best regards, Devon.

content:
y 30, 2016
												Don't Starve is an absolutely awesome survival game with a mesmorizing soundtrack and genuine dark, mysterious -- and sometimes satirical aura surrounding it.You start off with no weapons, no protection from the elements (aside from the preset clothing the character of your choice is given, which I will get more into later), and most of all, little knowledge as to where in the heck you are -- or how you got there (unless you watched some of the trailers.)You are spoken down to by this mysterious and dapper being sporting a traditional suit 'n tie, very reminiscent of the "G-Man" from the Half-Life series, he addresses you with a few words, and then poofs into nonexistance -- though you'll meet up with him in the near future.Don't Starve may SEEM like an absolutely pointless survival game with an infinite number of days, and that the clock won't stop ticking until you die (permadeath is a real thing, and you can't come back unless you've crafted yourself an effigy!) but fret not, there's more to this game than meets the eye!After what might be hours and hours of grinding, you'll find yourself coming across a variety of different scenarios - what looks like towns inhabited by xenophobic pig-men, stone ruins patrolled by mechanical 'robots', and much more. You'll find mysterious objects like "Box Thing", "Ring Thing", and they might just be miscellaneous objects you can just throw around and never pay any further mind to.. or they might be the key to 'beating' the game.My experience with the game has been absolutely splendid, I've encountered moments when I've been absolutely mobbed by armed pig-men, nearly scared to death by what looks like extraordinarily large turkies which pop out of bushes, and nerve-racking moments when my characters sanity begins to deterioate, causing haunting figures to appear..But lets break it down, shall we?PROS - A Survival Game: But a more well-designed and optimized one, constantly managed and won't be forsaken like what happens to most survivals.. (looking at you, DayZ)A Neat-o Crafting System: Items can be either very simplistic or slightly trivial to create, starting off is quite easy - mere flint and twigs and you have yourself either a Pickaxe, Shovel, or Chopping Axe, and can now chop down all them trees! ("Take that, Nature!" -- Wilson)Insanely Vague Story: This can go both ways; some people enjoy a story that's fleshed out, has alot of dialogue, and is clearly presented to you, but not this game - the game itself doesn't provide the player much information to work off of, conclusions will have to be made on your own end, and there are plenty of wiki's that'll help you further understand the game.Wild Encounters: There are alot of things to see in this game, from the occasional mysterious item surrounded by 'Evil Flowers' that'll drain your character's sanity to wormholes that'll consume you whole and transport you to a different part of the map. (Wormhole transport systems are great, yo.) Not to mention the shifting of seasons, an abundance of sinkholes leading to caves, and with the addition of DLCs, you could be taking down colossal giants or sailing the seas. You could also purchase "Don't Starve Together" (free if you've already bought the base game prior to the DLC's release) and try and survive with friends, or random people on the interwebs!A Variety Of Characters: Wilson is the preset character, and has no other special abilities other than the ability to grow the most manliest of beards (I mean, what more do you need than that, right?) but there are also little old ladies, muscular men afraid of the dark, and even a little pyromaniac girl and her dead sister at your disposal. All with their own unique abilities.CONS -Tedious Gameplay: There are people who have yet to beat the game despite having weeks logged into it, YouTubers still at the first stage whilst on Day 300, so on and so forth. So if you can't handle devotion or have commitment issues.. might wanna steer away from this game a bit.Rage Factor: The rage factor in this game depends on your progress, really. I wouldn't give two ♥♥♥♥♥ if I was brutally slaughtered by a spider on my first day.. but if you're the kind of person that has over 50 days, collected the items that'll help you progress through the game's "story" and are mistakenly killed by one of those ♥♥♥♥-headed frogs, well.. I'll set up a prayer circle to mend your broken heart and sanity.Game Length: This goes along with 'Tedious Gameplay', but just take a gander at the people who've actually 'beaten' the game and the hours THEY have. Or just go on YouTube and see for yourself.TL;DR - An absolutely phenomenial game, the music makes it all better. Don't buy it if you can't handle the whole survival concept, permadeath, and sheer overall length of the game.Graphics/Art: 4.5 out of 5Gameplay: 5 out of 5Story/Lore: 2.5 out of 5 (if not researched) 4 out of 5 (if researched)Overall Grade: 4 out of 5

content:
2014
												This game's art style is really what caught my eye in the first place, so I thought I would buy it whenever it went on sale.   Basically this is a game of survival and there are many things that can kill you. Your character is thrown into a world of vast wilderness and left to fend for himself/herself. Each world is randomly arranged and have random spawnings, keeping the game pretty fresh and new. You gather natural materials like sticks and rocks, make tools like axes and shovels, make traps or weapons to catch animals for food, set up campfires for survival, etc.  In the game you have three things you want to keep in check when surviving: Health, Hunger, and Sanity. If you lose your health, well, you can die. If you lose your hunger, you lose your health and die. If you lose your sanity, you start seeing things. Eventually your hallucinations become violent when you're insane and can hurt you. You can also unlock different and unique characters depending on in-game events or accomplishments.  The art style of this game in my opinion, is very unique and eye-catching. The game is very smooth and doesn't lag alot in general. (depending on how your computer is running though.) It does crash sometimes though. (I've had it crash twice on me.) I have also found a few glitches in the game (before Reign of Giants.)  This game gives you alot of chores for survival to keep you occupied, though sometimes it does get repeative. The worlds in Maxwell's Gate are the true challenges, whether its going through endless winters or rain. Or even hunted by hounds. Every world is filled with multiple monsters and critters to kill or survive from. There are also tons of material to collect for tons of creations you can unlock and survive with, giving this game some variety if you get that far. I really love the different characters in this game too, each one having their own charms and personalities. (My favorite character is Webber.) At times I get alot of creepy vibes from this game, especially at night when my sanity is getting low. And accomplished vibes whenever I survive from stuff. This game does have its charms, but it also has its fair share of flaws. Some of the flaws with this game is the repetiveness when trying to survive multiple times. Dying is definitely a big disappointment, especially when you get pretty far. This was not meant to be a very easy game though. The farther you get, the harder it gets. I would also say that some of the music (mostly in reign of giants) is a little too...cheesy, in a way? (I suppose its meant to be like that but still,) And some of the character's voices (which are instrument sounds) get a little annoying at times. Like Wilson's, for example, and when he gets hurt. The things they say give them alot of personality though. Especially Wendy. One more thing, sometimes (especially when you're a newbie) you encounter things that you have no idea how to deal with unless you look it up. (Which I suggest doing research before eating any of those colorful mushrooms unless you want to do it yourself.)   One last thing I have to say about this game is this: It's not for everyone. Some people (like me) will really like this game, and others might think its as boring as heck, everyone has their own tastes. So, if you're interested in it, I suggest checking this game out and maybe watch other people play it. Its a very fun game and can get time-consuming, I'd say its worth a buy. 8/10.Another thing: Multiplayer is comming soon! :D

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2016
												We are all familiar with the stereotypical grunting, primitive, idiotic caveman. But have you ever tried going outside (bear with me, we're all gamers here) and trying to make a simple tool with only rocks and sticks? Given the fact that they were born into a world where it was kill or be killed and every day was a fight for survival, it's incredible what the cavemen managed to accomplish.In Don't Starve, you take control of a scientist named Wilson*, who has just been thrown into a world as deadly as those the cavemen lived in. However, you have the advantage of knowledge. You know what fire is and how to make it. But you better make it quickly, because the night is fast approaching, and unlike the cavemen, your stars and moon do not provide light. At least, not enough to keep the shadows away.Welcome to a world of survival, where terrors lurk around every corner, where hunger and madness can prove more dangerous than wild beasts, where death is always a few steps behind. Can you gather the resources you need to defy your own doom? Can you build, research, and advance, all while keeping hunger and madness at bay? Can you build a civilization to stand the test of time? Oh wait, wrong game. Anyway, the world of Don't Starve is filled with horrors and dangers. And that's not even including the winter.Oh, yes. Winter. The most dangerous time of year. Perhaps you thought you were safe from starvation with your bountiful crops of fruit and vegetables. But when the ground freezes over, the plants become stagnate. Now, right when you thought you were safe and secure, you find yourself on the brink of disaster again. For winter is the season of the hunt. But what are you? The hunter? Or the prey? Brace yourself. Winter is coming.Wait, wrong thing again. In any case, this game is a must-have for those who love surviving by the skin of their teeth. The art style is reminiscent of Tim Burton animated movies, making the game truly unique in its field. The gameplay is great, either with keyboard and mouse or with the steam controller. At the time of writing this review, I've played 70 hours of Don't Starve, and I've only scratched the surface. Maybe that's just because I suck at it, but even so I enjoy it immensely. And I haven't even gotten started on the DLC's yet!*Wilson is the default character, but there are many others, including Willow the Firestarter, Wolfgang the Strongman, and Woody the... well, you'll see. ;-)

content:
23, 2013
												Excelente survival lleno de contenido y con considerable dificultad. No sólo tenés que cuidarte de no morir de hambre, sino que también tenés que cuidar tu estabilidad mental, tu vida, el no morirte de frío, que no te parta un rayo en las tormentas, que no te quedes a oscuras, etc. Cada día el juego se hace más complicado y los mismos varían su duración según las estaciones, a la noche sí o sí necesitás estar en una zona con luz o la comés en 5 segundos, literalmente. Se pueden recolectar cientos de cosas y con los mismos craftear otras cientas, todo con un útil uso. Con respecto a la comida, podés cocinarla en cualquier fogata y más adelante hacer recetas en el crack pot. La misma se pudre si no la consumís, aunque la guardes en la heladera, cosa que sólo retrasa el enpudrecimiento.El modo aventura consiste de 5 "mapas" que presentan un reto, por ejemplo en uno es todo el tiempo invierno. Le da un sentido al juego con el final, el cual dudo ver porque es bastante jodido que lo pase.Es un excelente juego que da para cientos de horas por su infinita rejugabilidad y encima está a muy bajo precio, aparte de estar genial. Un MUST HAVE en toda regla.

content:
5, 2014
-Quick Review-Don’t Starve raises the bar on “survival games”, while many games hold your hand, or let you have an easier game mode, Don’t Starve is actually the opposite, when I start to lose in don’t starve, I feel the game kicking me while I’m down.


YouTube™ Video: Atratzu Reviews: Don't Starve - But he's still very Hungry 

			Views: 92		

			Atratzu is blessed and plagued with a very active metabolism, this is good because he stays skinny... but he's always hungry and trying not to starve. Tired of my puns yet?		

-Detailed breakdown review-Story:  "Say pal, you don't look so good. You better find something to eat before night comes!" Those are words to live by. I haven’t actually finished the story myself, I’m still working on that, (I prefer to just explore and try to live as long as I can). I would recommend the trailer[s] to anyone who would like to know more about the story.Some things just aren’t able to be put into words, and the trailer with the conversation between Wilson and Maxwell is just summed up best by watching the trailer.


Well, I found the door... too bad I'm a sucker for punishment. *walks away* 
A Screenshot of Don't Starve
By: Atratzu




Game Play: The controls are quite straight forward, you can control how your character moves with ASDW, or by clicking on the ground/objects, or click and holding down the mouse button. Your inventory is very limited, but I can’t complain about that, it simply requires you to make backpacks/chests/etc.There are three “resources” to juggle in don’t starve: Sanity, Hunger, Health. As the game itself implies, don’t let yourself be hungry for too long, once your hunger drops to zero, your health drains very fast until you die. Once your health is gone, you’re dead. Sanity is an interesting resource, but I’ll let you find out why for yourself if you get the game.


New Defenses are successful! 
A Screenshot of Don't Starve
By: Atratzu




Price: Don’t starve costs $14.99 (as of July 25, 2014) and the DLC “Reign of Giants “is $4.99. Apparently this summer there’s supposed to be an expansion to allow the game to become multiplayer, I’m looking forward to playing with friends on this great survival game.Thankfully for those who already own the game and the DLC, you don’t need to worry about buying anything else, but for those that don’t own the game; the price will be increased to $19.99. I’ve put 52 hours into the game so far, I have no doubt I will go back to playing more of this game, so regardless of when you get the game I feel the price is very fair. Conclusion: I used to say that if I had to own only one game, It would come down to a three way tie between "Minecraft", "Terraria", and "Don't Starve". All three are excellent games, and all three have different play styles, Don't Starve is probably the most unique.http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=395630283------Edits and updates------Edit/Update January 13, 2015:Here's the URL to see my review for Don't Starve TogetherEdit/Update September 18, 2015:Added screenshots to the review.Here's the URL to see my review for  Don't Starve Reign of Giants DLCEdit/Update February 29, 2016:Added YouTube Video Review Link!

content:
ber 22, 2016
												I already reviewed this game, though I didn't do it justice the first time. This is by far the most addicting game I have ever played, and its stood strong for three years since its release back in 2013, and given that I have managed to survive for over 250 days in a world I generated two months ago, I felt it proper to give my overall thoughts on the game in general. I still recommend it for someone looking for a challenge, and anybody interested in this should definately give it a try, since it does offer a lot that other survival games do not have. On top of managing hunger, you need to manage sanity loss and health as well, making for a challenging experience. With Reign of Giants and Shipwrecked DLC, you can further expand your worlds with new challenges and items to craft. With an endless until you die Sandbox mode, and a portal to an Adventure Mode that offers six harder more challenging worlds, the replayabillity is near endless, with each world generating a completely different world layout every time.Also, if you end up liking this and would like to play it with friends or strangers, I'd suggest to take a look at Don't Starve Together, the standalone multiplayer version of Don't Starve, complete with all new content and the Reign of Giants expansion content already included with the game.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 7, 2016
												This is a very tentative upvote on my part.There isn't anything objectionable about this game; the aesthetics are excellent, the system in place is very well put together. However, I think this is much a case of YMMV on if it's fun for you or not. In my case I found myself searching for a goal and not finding one, which borked any reason I might have to continue playing beyond the first 10 or so runs. Sustaining interest by burning down the forest all through the night can only work for so long.If you are considering buying this game, look to the mechanics as you make your choice. Do you enjoy a procedural world where the only thing to do is gather resources and survive as long as you can? Then this is the game for you. If you need a goal the game gives you to work towards in order to maintain your motivation to play, then bypass it.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2014
												:dsham:Isometric view survival game with quite unique, memorable art style.As you may imagine from the title, focus here is on non-combat survival - fighting hunger and adverse environmental conditions like weather or darkness at night. Granted, monsters are out there to get you as well.The game is rather open ended, no clear goals other than survival, although there's an adventure mode to find, which is a more focused challenge.You're definitely meant to discover things yourself on the go, through many deaths of you, forging mad in-game survival skills in fires of hell. If you're looking through guides, wikias, videos... you are somewhat missing the point and missing out great deal on the intended "fun".And good riddance, as far as I am concerned, and wikia contributors be praised. Otherwise game is very unfair, puts constant pressure on you, demands great deal from you yet explains nothing, all the while throwing curve balls at you from all possible directions simultaneously and just waiting for any suitable moment to sucker punch you with extreme prejudice. And on top of that this is perma death. You screw up royally, you're out of luck, and have to start from zero on a new random world (but hopefully with more experience now to do better; also I should say there's a way to secure resurrection, but not like it's fool proof, so the royal screw up is always an option).Seriously, eff that noise. I'm pretty sure die hard fans who went through this without any external help are suffering from Stockholm syndrome.As you may see I'm not entirely a fan of the frantic gameplay and main design decisions in general, but I cannot claim the game is bad. What it wants to do, it does very well, and it's an interesting experience to get out of your comfort zone, change the pace a little. Although I did get me some external help on how to survive in this hell, missing a lot of the intended "fun", I had some quality time nonetheless to appreciate this title and I don't regret it.It's not really that hard to set up some nice sustainable camp and a variety of defenses from weekly wake up call, you can even set up reasonable supplies despite your main focus here - food - being perishable... It's just that at some point this becomes a chore that prevents you from doing the real good parts. At least IMHOI had way more actual fun with, say, Terraria, which has quite a different focus - on combat and exploration, with ample addition of creative projects you can undertake, where gathering up resources is a means to an end not your primary worry. I guess I like to mess around in games, especially such that promise sandbox experience, at my own pace, rather than being constantly rushed and pushed and with perma death looming on the horizon to make me lose my entire progress. For the latter, I'd rather play some rogue-lites with well balanced pacing.You may probably get bit philosophical about this and claim this game gets it real... Too real for my taste, I guess. Where's my goddarned escapism, eh?Oh, a final thought, though - the above mostly concerns default settings, but actually the game is extremely configurable so once you do get the taste of the intended default experience, you can tweak practically every aspect of the game a lot to match your tastes and perhaps make it easier or even more difficult. Workshop support also something to consider, and official DLC that adds two more seasons, overheating on top of freezing and some other elements, is also something to mix things up. So despite my whining above you can really get a lot from this title, so give it a shot if you have a chance.:dsham:

content:
, 2014
												Let me start this review by telling you how I absolutely LOVE this game. Do note that this review contains spoilers and stuff that might ruin parts of discovery and fun in the game I cannot put my love for this game in words but I will try to explain some points of why I believe this is the revolutionary game that help video games progress as form of art.--------------------------------------First of all let me start by telling about the social commentaty this game makes. I know it's hard to see the social commentary in a game where you're all alone in the wilderness but it's there to be found. The social commentary is subtle and told in a very dark soul-ish way which is leaving hints and bits of information that the player figures out. There are multiple parts implying that the silent protagonist is a female-to-male transgender. For example the protagonist has very feminine jaw and chin. He also has feminine hair with lots of volume. Another not so noticed part is the depression in his eyes. Many think the depression is from being alone in the wilderness and darkness of the world. Well they're wrong. It is from the depression caused by being transgender and being oppressed by white cis men and women.---------------------------------Now to the story of the game. I know this is hard to believe for most people, even the most diehard fans of the game, but the game doesnt actually happen in wilderness but inside the person's dreams. The story is very metaphorical about everything. The safety of fire means support of loved ones when transitioning to opposite gender. The angry animals of the wilderness represent the people who are against his transitioning into a man. The neutral animals/critters are considered bypassers. Those are the people he is able to interact without the people being rude/different towards him just for being transgender.The day and night cycle represent the mood swing caused by hormones in transition. While this is not social commentary, it tells about how reality reflects to his dream which the game is. This mechanism is one of the subtle things that make this game a masterpiece.------------------------------We're done with the story now, lets progress to the gameplay.The gameplay is something completely fresh. You start of in a hostile world of no comfort, like transgender person is before getting his/her support for transitioning. Slowly you start gathering materials to get fire. The materials represent bits of trust you build up with other people. Fire represents, like I earlier explained, the support. This is a big gameplay aspect that makes this game extremely good.Another excellent game mechanic is the hunger mechanic. Hunger reflects upon the character's need for love. If he is let without love, he will most likely die. In the dream he isnt just likely to die if the hunger for love isnt fed, he will die.-------------------------------I know this might be shocking to even most diehard fans but everything in this review was researched for a very long time. I spent countless hours finding out all of this and much more. I didnt include everything I found out in this review because I wanted to keep this as a Steam review and not a full review for a bigger site. If you're hungry for more information and stuff I've found out, just ask me.This concludes my review and I strongly recommend everyone to play this.If you're big fan of art games, this is a must have.

content:
, 2016
												Okay, here's something based on a true story - My first death in this game was due to stravation. It's the name of the game, I'm just that great of a player.Don't Starve is a nice little Indie game, I like it and I reccomend others to try it as well. At first I thought I wouldn't like it because I thought it just had the same concept as any other survival game, you get materials, don't die, and build stuff. I actually compared it to Minecraft. That was a mistake. This is obviously nothing like Minecraft, and it even isn't as generic as most other surivial based games. When I first started playing I fell in love with the game. It was fun learning how to do everything, exploring the world, and trying not to starve. The art style is nice and unique and gameplay aint half bad, I personally use the keyboard and the mouse, but it can be played completely with your mouse if you want to and it had controller support as well.Most people will probably skip the single player game and get Don't Starve Together but I suggest getting Don't Starve as well. It can prepare you for playing co-op in Together as you learn the ins and outs of everything, that and the fact they are two completely diffrent games in terms of conent.Don't Starve Together only has the base game and some asepcts of the Reign of Giants DLC, along with some Don't Starve Together exclusive conent. The base game however has 2 DLCs thus far, Shipwrecked completely changing the game as if it was a full conversion mod, and also the base game has Adventure Mode, in which you put your skills to the test to surivie the world and solve the puzzles to finish the game.This game is endless hours of fun and it's quite easy to get started and find yourself doing good. The only downside is that when you do die (for good) You loose your world and everything and you have to start over, I personally don't like perminant death but I've gotten used to it in Don't Starve because sometimes you get even better world spawns and finds then you did on your previous run. Also the lore now is a little bit outdate as the lore in Don't Starve Together is the canon lore, and you can't dress up with skins in the base game. Some monsters are really hard to fight, so if you look to actually move up from fighting spiders and beefalo, you will find a challange in fighting them, that's really the only time the game gets hard other then that it's pretty relaxing.The small downsides apart, the game is great and worth your time to play. Great time killer. Also mods can make your life easier if you do struggle with the harder monsters like I do. (who thought hounds were a good idea?)

												The title says it all. Don't Starve is one of those addictive survival games, delivering you with the idea that your character(s) lives are at stake. Alike many other survival games it aims to make the idea of food a priority, and the rest will seamlessly fall into place. However Don't Starve wouldn't be complete without its amazing mod support, in which you can build new stuctures or delve into new stories. The options are endless! Some of the mods can't support some of the options in the vanilla game, causes crashes and save wiping issues. Faced with alot of hideous monsters and natural dangers, Don't Starve is one of the best survival games on the market!Pros: Fun survival, great mod support.       Cons: Mods can cause crashes, would love to see it multiplayer~8.5/10~

content:
6, 2014
												Don't Starve is an indie game about...not starving. Or getting killed by spiders. Or werepigs. Or stupid, randomly spawning dogs...or, well, there's a lot of ways to die in this game besides just starving, and I'll leave it at that. Overall, it's a rewarding, if not incredibly challenging, experience.Usually, indie games are highlighted by either their story, design or gameplay, which may prove significantly more innovative or intriguing than your average AAA game. That's why we buy them. Don't Starve is...a little bit different, to say the least, in that it's not all that inspiring in terms of story or gameplay. Here's the story: you don't want to starve, and also there's this dapper looking gentleman who appears to be channeling the ghost of a douchy harmonium. In terms of gameplay, point-and-click or use WASD to move around and interact with your environment, etc, etc. It's nothing that special.BUT! The design and presentation of the game make up for this apparent lack and reveal that the game itself is not nearly as lacking as it may seem to the wandering eyes of you potential buyers. In terms of design, its quirky, dark, funny and heavily Tim Burton-ized. The art style is simple enough that it doesn't overstep the abilities of its indie designers but still appears fresh, pretty and new, and each character you unlock through surviving longer and longer is unique, with his or her own set of perks and weaknesses that can be amusing, annoying or just plain scary. There's a girl who's dead twin literally follows her around, or a lumberjack with a possessed axe and a dark, beaver-based secret. Personally, I hope for more characters to be added to the vanilla game or perhaps as DLC because the current roster gets unlocked pretty quickly on an good three or four runs through the game. Still, these characters are more interesting than what you'll pick up from most games at this price.And when you do delve deep into this game after many, many, many trial runs, you'll discover that there's actually a lot of lore and story to this world. This mostly begins after entering Adventure Mode (and if you die in this mode, it doesn't affect your progress in the sandbox world), which can be done by opening a door randomly generated in any of your played worlds. You progress through five unique and challenging worlds, and along the way, you get a chance to see some of this lore and will probably hunger for more. Don't Starve leaves a lot more questions unanswered than I would like, but it's all to the cruelly addicting benefit of the game itself.Finally, I should address the difficulty of this game. You probably won't make it past the first five or so days on your first try without customizing the world. It's not an easy game, lacks any form of tutorial at all and all enemies, from bosses to weak spiders, can be found in the overworld on Day 1. Yes, there are one-time respawn points if you find them, but if you die, then it's over. Sometimes those respawn points don't even spawn. Your forty days of surviving through the turmoil of winter? Screw it! Never happened! And that does kind of suck, but it all adds to the tension and atmosphere of the game itself. You don't get a tutorial in the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ woods! No one saves you when you decide to attack a herd of water buffalo with a stick of meat! And that mushroom over there? What does it do? Oh wait, it drains all of your sanity and makes shadow creatures in your head eat off your face. That'll learn ya.So yes, Don't Starve is difficult, especially during the winter months. But this is a survival game about surviving in a magical survival forest full of pop culture references and musical instruments. It's not supposed to be easy. And I'll tell you, there's nothing more rewarding than making it past your longest survival time. And if it's too hard, then you can tweak the spawning in a customized world so that only friendly bunnies and happy flowers populate your world. And occasionally, Satanic trees possessed with the vengeance of a thousand sundered splinters will pop up and absolutely wreck everything you hold dear and precious, as was intended by the Founding Fathers.

Got cocky and tried to get back to my home, and then froze to death. All for some gold.Pros: Replayability: This game almost makes you want to hit retry, and if you find yourself bored, download some mods. DLC: Reign of giants is a DLC that changes how you play your game, adding 2 seasons, and a handful of new mobs to farm, kill, or be killed by.Roguelike: This makes the game exciting, if you were to respawn constantly It would detract from the difficulty of the game(IMO)Cons:Minor bugs that screw with my control settingsOverall I give this game no rating because ratings suck. Buy the game if you like roguelike games. Please don't get it if you have the intentions to play something similar to minecraft.Webber is the best...

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
Don't Starve is a survival/resource management sandbox game, and whether or not you enjoy it will depend largely upon how much fun you can have in said sandbox. The game is largely undirected; you're literally dropped in a field and told, fittingly, not to starve to death. After that you gather resources, craft items, and try to find a way out of the strange world you inhabit.There's a lot of game to explore. Each successive world is randomly generated and all are thus challenging in different ways. Nothing is ever explained; you learn by doing and exploring. Sadly, the various characters you unlock change things minorly at best, and the core gameplay never really changes: collect things, craft things, try not to die or go insane (and, with the new expansion, try not to freeze or overheat).Don't Starve good game, but not one I liked. I found the resource management tedious, and although the exploration and investigative elements were compelling, the constant ticking clock of starvation and insanity and freezing and overheating was too oppressive for me to enjoy myself.

content:
9, 2014
												At first when I saw this game I never thought much about it. Until one of my friends modded it a few months ago. Now at that time I had no clue on how to mod videogames, and was too lazy to do so. Until a couple of months ago I had tons of free time, and decided to give modding a try. After yet another friend brought this game I was reminded of this game. So since I've been modding 3D games such as Left4Dead2, I decided what the heck, I'll buy this game and give the modding at try.After playing a none-custom game, I died the first day from not getting up a fire up in time. This made me want to try again, this time I survivaled 3 days, dying by going insane from not knowing how to keep sane. But with each new game I learned how things worked and what creatures are friendly and need to be avioded. After playing it a few hours I have found that this game is INCREDIBLY addicting.The world randomly generates so every play through is a new experience, keeping each game feeling fresh. You never know when you'll spawn in the middle of nowhere, in a rich in resources pig village, or right next to a spider nest or pack of blood thirsty hounds. Not only that, since I do own Reign of Giants dlc you must watch out for the seasons, if you customize your world settings to be more advanced you may be a unlucky person to spawn in summer or winter, where you can easily overheat or freeze to death. The game is unforgiving, it tries it's hardest to kill you but with each gameplay you learn to survive longer.The game has a very unique-looking style. It reminds me a little of a Tim Buton-like style, and it's very nice to look at. The creatures are creative too, along with each character you can unlock with their different abilities. I then tried my hand at modding the game and found that it is VERY easy to mod. Now I do have more experience modding harder games so those without modding experience might take a little longer to learn than someone will some experience, but since the games community and the games staff is generous and very willing to help you with modding it. You'll defiantly get the hang of it eventually. There are also plenty of videos to help you out with it.I defiantly reccommend buying this game, it is worth every penny. With multiplayer coming out soon you'll be able to enjoy the game with your friends.

content:
10, 2014
												Tim Burton meets Gathering / Crafting adventure game goodness.This game captures my imagination like very few others. What it lacks in immersion it makes up for in truckloads of creativity and art originality.Some of the mechanics feel a little "left by the wayside" such as combat, which to me has always seemed to work a little haphazzardly. But the exploration and curiosity factor are so over the top its very easy to forget such things might get in your way.The music and sound fit perfectly with the art style in a melancholy yet purposeful romp through a dark and twisted wonderland of putrid or warped settings.I've had a blast playing Don't Starve, on and off Steam. Don't let my Steam playtime fool you, I'm a long standing supporter of Don't Starve and highly recommend it to anyone with a penchant for slightly warped or morbid yet humorous adventures.

content:
, 2014
												Review written after purchasing the DLCAbout the Basic Game:Alright lets get it straight and simple: the basic game is an extremly hard, easily modable and overall fun survival game. Interesting mechanics, good combat mechanics, and in general no items are completly useless. Even if you allow your food to rot because you do not have a fridge yet to slow spoilage down it will still have a use as fertilizer. Every damn item has a use in this game and that happens not that often. No item is outperformed by another one. Each of them have flaws. Even "inferior" stone/flint which break more easily have a nice advantage over gold tools: They are alot cheaper to craft. Though the concept of gold tools is kinda stereotypic because gold is a really soft material... oh well. Oh and btw, you dont want to be in the darkness without a light.Creative and unique enemies with relativly decent movement patterns which will hit hard if you do not respect them as a propper enemy (though the regular spiders are a bit weak), fairly expensiv but powerfull ranged weapons, a good, well balanced armor system and very lovely characters to play with. You can even play as the main antagonist "Maxwell" if you finish the game. Each character has its own unique abilities giving him perks to support his survival in some way and having disadvantages making certain things harder. For instance Wilson: That character is unlocked from the beginning. He has very well balanced stats and as a special perk he grows a beard. Doesnt sound that special right? But the beard can be shaved and used as an effigy of himself in order to give him another try in case he dies. And extra lifes are EXTREMLY HARD to obtain in the game. Other characters like Woodie, a canadian lumberjack, has a fear of birds and therefor looses sanity near them, but brings his own unbreakable axe, a HUGE advantage over other characters. Also he is "cursed" which affects him at certain days (not spoiling too much).So after hinting on sanitiy theres also a very inspiring sanity/insanity system. Surviving in a lone, strange world with different laws of physics can be harsh. Where everything you encounter might kill you you might turn insane. Well thats the case in the game: You slowly loose your sanity if certain events are happening. For instance if you are in the dusk, exposed to certain terrifying hostiles or if you are close to some "evil flowers" which are poisoning the air arround them letting you go insane slowly. As sanity drops the character begins to hear weird noises, voices and starts hallucinating draining his sanity further. Once he is over a certain threshhold those "hallucinations" manifest and you have to fight extremly powerfull, otherworldly monsters who could have come from Lovecraft himself. Those "shadows" are able to teleport and as already said hard to kill. You have to gain sanity by doing "sane" things, like picking a few dozens of flowers, then throwing them away (well however that should keep you sane), wearing civilized clothes or killing said shadows. You need to be insane once in a while in order to survive alot better because said shadows drop a very usefull material. Lastly I like to point out the weather/season system: In the standard game without the DLC there are 2 seasons: Summer and Winter. Summer is relativly easy, you basicly setup your camp, gain materials, fight monsters, survive. Winter turns the game alot harder. You will start freezing without a fire or propper clothing, have trouble finding food (good luck farming in winter) and a giant mob called deerclops will spawn at some point who has to be killed in order to protect your camp and your hard work. Winter plays completly different then the regular seasons.And theres alot more content to explore then those highlights I listed up + the community really produces high quality mods for the game.So now to the DLC:I hate DLCs... usually. But if its that well done and for a price of 4.99$ then I can just say "Go ahead buy it now". It adds the remaining 2 seasons and turns summer into a drought. In spring you have to fight with dampness of your character because of frequent rain. Summer is a drought which means plants will wither and dont yield food, heat will affect you badly similar to winters cold, trees, plants, mobs, items on the ground, you etc will combust once in a while if its burnable and faster food spoilage will occur. Autumn is by far the most peacefull season... untill you encounter the Giant in autumn which is extremly hard to fight. He is basicly a far stronger version then winters deerclops and has a "beserk attack" where he (or it) will rush towards you destroying any contraptions you build and derooting trees. He will eat any food he can find if left alone and only turns hostile if you hinder him from eating. Thats just 1 giant. There is 1 giant for each season now, and the deerclops for winter got rebalanced and got a powerfull "icicle erruption" as a stomp attack causing icy spears to appear infront of him out of the ground. With all the new seasons, new giants/bosses and new survival mechanics... basicly all the content comes a heck of more items. Again all of them have uses and none of them are completly useless. And all of them are very balanced. Overall a very good "DLC" which I would rather call an addon because of the sheer mass of content it dumps on you. Oh and you get to play 2 new unique, high quality, characters with unique abilities. No reskins or anything like the stuff you get from bigger "AAA" companies. This DLC worths the money and is a great addition to the main game. I highly recomment getting both, Main game and DLC, its an awesome, joyfull yet extremly hard game. If you fail and die you lost everything if you dont have any kinds of resurrection methods. Its the thrill of loosing anything which makes the game really fun. And there are alot of mods out there, some just adding new items, some which add completly new "levels" to play as. Or just unique characters like a Weavile, The red Soldier (Jane Doe) from TF2, The Heavy from TF2, several LoL Champions or completly original characters with unique abilities (William J. Dannigar (hopefully I wrote that name right)). So go get the game if you want a challenge. Its fun and really enjoyable.-Sigma.

												The game is indeed a great survival adventure and I don't regret wanting it and then buying it at all, but I also can't deny that I'm pretty disappointed in developer's choice of not supporting "Steam achievements". I like tracking my progress and my dedication for a game through those achievements, and displaying those was often the only way of showing off. I don't mind the perma-death and the frustration that comes with it, it's a survival game after all. It reminds me quite a lot of those WC3 survival maps, which is a good thing cause those were really fun, but also of Faster Than Light because of the frustration and perma-death parts.Anyway, the game is awesome, artsy without getting fancy, complex without getting complicated, and incredibly addictive. I can hardly wait the arrival of the multiplayer mode too.

												Simply Fantastic.  Can't say I've seen anything like it in all my gaming years (over 20  years now).In a class of its own, despite being a survival game.When I saw the game in the Steam store, I watched the videos, read some reviews, then checked out the community and workshop.  The art direction of this series has always intrigued me, I just wasn't sure if it was something I could get in to.The game went on Sale this week, so I picked it up.  It's safe to say, 'the rest is history'.What an amazing little survival game!  I literally have to watch myself with this one, because what seems like 15-20min ends up being an hour or two, without even batting an eye about it.  The sounds, music, mechanics, map design, 'critter' art and designs, all of it are just superb, and unique.The game runs flawlessly, without any hiccups, so far.  The modding community for this game is alive and well, ensuring that this series won't be going away anytime soon.I highly recommend this game to ANY kind of gamer, it will surprise you!  I haven't really played the "Together" version yet, but I'm quite certain it will only add even more fun to the game, and without a doubt, some hillarious moments!5/5 Stars for this one.  Buy it.  Play it.  I'm not responsible for any addiction that occurs there-after.  ;)
